try again laterInvalid EmailA suspected technical glitch in the benefits system means families across the country have been getting some of their money early. The error has paid out both sickness benefit Employment and Support Allowanceand Jobseekers Allowance to people across the country. Usually, both those benefits are paid in one lump sum fortnightly. But many claimants who were due to be paid next week have received half their payment already. The Department for Work and Pensionsattempted to calm fears today by insisting everyone will get the second half of their payment on the correct day.  It is understood the glitch extends to an unknown number of benefit claimants spread throughout all regions of the UK, including Northern Ireland. One claimant tweeted: Id hoped Theresa May had decided we should get an Xmas bonus! Another complained the payment came with no explanation, no solution, no help. Guidance on the DWPs website confirms: If your ESA payment is due in the week starting  January , you might be paid half of it early in the week starting  December . The other half of your payment will be paid on the correct day. Your next fortnightly ESA payment will be paid as normal. If your JSA payment is due in the week starting  January , you might be paid half of it early in the week starting  December . Are you affected  Get in touch using the form below. If your JSA payment is due in the week starting  January , you might be paid half of it early in the week starting  January .The other half of your payment will be paid on the correct day. Your next fortnightly JSA payment will be paid as normal. Its not yet known how many claimants are affected or how to knowyou are one of them, other than checking your bank account. A DWP spokesperson said: “Some ESA claimants may have received an early half of their fortnightly payment. These claimants will now receive the second half of their payment on their usual pay date. “No one has lost out and all ESA claimants will be paid on time. “Staff are available to offer guidance for those seeking further support.”

title: most tories believe theresa bungling
story: NewsMost Tories believe Theresa May is bungling Brexit negotiationsA poll of Conservative members delivers a damning verdict on the Governments handling of the withdrawlShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  JAN NewsTheresa May has admitted she will not fight another general election "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNearly  in  Tory members think the Government is bungling Brexit negotiations, a scathing poll reveals today. In a damning blow to Theresa May’s strategy, % of Conservative members believe she is making a mess of withdrawal. Just % of , Conservative members surveyed support the Prime Minister’s departure deal. It comes as she was urged to delay the “meaningful vote” on her Brexit deal for a second time. MPs are due to vote on her pact in the week starting January . But former Brexit Secretary David Davis believes the crunch Commons showdown could be shelved againMrs May is heading for defeat.  His comments come as the PM prepares to meet EU leaders and seek further “clarications” in a bid to persuade sceptical MPs to back her deal. But a spokeswoman for EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said bloc leaders “have been very clear that it will not be renegotiated, what is on the table”. Blasting the PM’s pact, Mr Davis wrote in the : “The withdrawal agreement does not respect the referendum result. “That is why the meaningful vote had to be delayed and one wonderseven the January vote will go ahead. “Attempts to frighten MPs into supporting it are unlikely to work, because voting down this substandard deal will not result in no Brexit.”  A survey of Tory members reveals the struggle Mrs May faces to convince her own party to back her plan. Opposition to the deal among activists outweighs support by % to %, according to the Party Members Project for Queen Mary University of London and Sussex University. Some % think her agreement fails to respect the result of the  referendum, with % saying it does. In another hammer blow to her bid to force the deal through Parliament, only % of Tory members would vote for it, compared to % who would vote to quit without a pact. Mrs May, who has admitted she will not fight another general election, hoped MPs would rally round her pact after meeting constituents over Christmas.  But the survey suggests opposition among activists is even stronger than on her own backbenches. Professor Tim Bale, of Queen Mary University London, said: “It would be fair to say that the Tory grassroots are,not obsessed, then consumed by Brexit. “But what is really striking is how little support there is at the Tory grassroots for Mrs May’s deal. “Generally, Conservative Party members, like most voters of whatever ilk, think the government has made a mess of negotiating Brexit.” Ministers have denied claims they are trying to drum up support for the PM’s plan by running “Project Fear II” after issuing a series of warnings highlighting the risks of crashing out without a deal. But Prof Bale said: “Tory members – like Tory voters – are utterly unconvinced, despite their own government’s best recent efforts, that a no-deal Brexit would cause serious disruption. “Some % of voters currently intending to support the Conservatives think the warnings are ‘exaggerated or invented’ – a figure that rises to % among Tory members. “Meanwhile, those members are convinced by a margin of % to % that leaving without a deal would have a positive rather than a negative effect on Britain’s economy in the medium to long term.” He added: “Mrs May has failed not only to convince the country and quite probably Parliament that her Brexit deal is a good one, she has also failed to convince the party faithful.” Environment Secretary Michael Gove highlighted the risks of no-deal departure again yesterday. The “turbulence which will be generated by our departure without a deal would be considerable”, he told the Oxford Farming Conference. Tarfs, border checks, potential delays for recognising certain organic products and labour pressures would add to food producers’ costs. “Nobody can be blithe or blase about the real impacts on food producers in this country of leaving without the deal,” said the leading Brexiteer. “It would hit worst those who are our smaller farmers and farm businesses.”

title: ros wynne jones amber rudd
story: NewsopinionRos Wynne-Jones: Amber Rudd should make ending Tory welfare cruelty her resolutionAmber Rudds tweet about welfare came on same day the Mirror revealed Dean Lovell-Payne tried to take his own le while on the phone to the DWP - after waiting  weeks for his Universal Credit to arriveShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  JAN NewsopinionAmber Rudd tweeted about a fairer welfare system - but any changes will have come too late for Dean "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter a record-breaking shyChristmas for foodbanks, there came this tweet from Amber Rudd, the new Secretary of State for Work and Pensions. “Not usually one for New Year’s Resolutions,” the former Home shySecretary wrote, “but here are mine + one hope… Make our welfare system work better and fairer for women. Help claimants into work and shyfinancial independence. Get help more quickly to those who need it. Less violent discourse in our politics.” Her tweet came the same day the Mirror revealed former ambulance worker Dean Lovell-Payne tried to take his own le while on the phone to the DWP after waiting a staggering  weeks for his first Universal Credit payment to arrive. Dean’s le had been changed by a fall – something that could happen to anyone.   But, cruelly, he was left thinking his le insurance would pay out more quickly than the DWP to support his we and kids. Of all the Christmases since the Tories turbocharged austerity in  – the ones with the bedroom tax, and cuts to Personal Independence Payments and Disability Living shyAllowance – this may have been the cruellest Christmas yet. The first for millions on Universal Credit. Not only were people forced to spend the festive season with empty cupboards due to the built in “five-week wait”, but Universal Credit has introduced “conditionality” – i.e. shysanctions – to millions who have never experienced it before. That’s one of the things making UC a hostile environment for claimants.   The stories of that cruelty are only just beginning, but given they will apply to more and more people,  looks set to be a story of hunger and poverty for more people. This year, despite having just been told by UN shyrapporteur Professor Philip Alston that the UK’s high child poverty rate was “not just a disgrace, but a social calamity and an economic disaster, all rolled into one”, the Tories will use Brexit as a reason not to do anything to change the misery austerity is wreaking via welfare reform. They will say there’s no shyparliamentary time, and no political “oxygen” left. This is particularly stupid – or clever – given that how millions of people feel about Brexit is directly defined by how hopeless and worthless they feel they and their community are to the elites running the country.   Since the vote in , the Government has had two years to soften austerity, but has done nothing apart from spout some empty jam-tomorrow rhetoric about just- about-managing families. As a Remainer, Rudd might want to think hard about this. Her tweet suggests there is some kind of rocket science to making the welfare system fairer or getting help to people more quickly. The fact is Iain Duncan Smith’s reforms were conceived to make the welfare system less fair – harsher, more cruel. They were specically designed to get help to people more slowly – that’s why there’s a five- week wait. To save the welfare bill five weeks of money per person. It’s not some mysterious alchemy. It’s pretty easy to do some immediate things. Rudd’s first five quick-fix new year’s shyresolutions should be to stop the five-week wait, restore the work allowance in UC, drop sanctions across the benefit system, pause UC rollout, and reverse cuts to disabled people. All this would see foodbanks closing, not opening. Rudd is already shyremembered for one hostile shyenvironment after she was forced to resign amid the Windrush scandal. The Tories have been at it again over Christmas. Talking up the arrival of a small number of people arriving by boat to the UK the way Donald Trump talks up the “migrant caravan” in America. It creates a perception of a deluge of migrants. This is no longer Rudd’s shydepartment. But she has the chance to do shysomething about the Tories’ other most hostile environment – for shystruggling people who need the support of the welfare state. Leaver Iain Duncan Smith has helped his Brexit cause with his brutal “reforms”. The hard lives people are living were one of the key motivators for people to vote for Brexit. When you have nothing, you have nothing to lose by a radical overhaul of our contract with the world. Hostility breeds more hostility. Rudd may have done the Tory right’s dirty work at the Home Office but she’s not a wild-eyed ideologue. It may be there is too little time left now to make a dference. But opening the taps and softening austerity is the way to a softer Brexit. Meanwhile, ending austerity and giving people and communities hope for the future, attacking the causes of the first Brexit vote, is the only path to a second referendum. Perhaps that’s what Rudd’s tweet was about. Meanwhile, she did get one thing right. As we begin a new year afresh, we should all sign up to her final new year’s resolution, “less violent discourse in our politics”.

title: theresa mays double brexit blow
story: NewsTheresa Mays double Brexit blow as DUP and Irish PM line up to trash her dealThe DUPs Nigel Dodds dashed Downing Streets hopes of a breakthrough - and Irish PM Leo Varadkar piled on the painShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  JAN NewsThe DUPs Nigel Dodds "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEmbattled Theresa May’s hopes of winning support for her Brexit plan were dashed over lunch with the DUP tonight. The Prime Minister’s bid to shore-up backing for her Brussels pact was looking increasingly fruitless after she hosted the party’s Westminster leader Nigel Dodds in No. Downing Street had hoped for a breakthrough, but he emerged saying: “The withdrawal agreement, as currently proposed, flies in the face of the government’s commitments on Northern Ireland as we leave the EU.” EU leaders crushed chances of offering Mrs May concessions to win over the DUP and her own backbenchers. She wants reassurances the Irish backstop - designed to prevent checks on the -mile frontier between the North and the Republic under a no-deal departure - will not be indefinite.  Torpedoing the bid, EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker’s spokeswoman said: “We are not renegotiating what is on the table. “Our solutions are on the table, we are ready to listen but at this stage there are no further meetings and the EU  leaders have been very clear that it will not be renegotiated what is on the table.” Mr Juncker “reiterated very clearly that we have put all the solutions on the table and now it is up the British people and MPs to decide on the next steps”, in an interview last month, she added. Meanwhile, speaking after talks with German counterpart Angela Merkel, Irish PM Leo Varadkar piled the pain on Mrs May. He said: “We’re happy to offer reassurances and guarantees to the UK, but not reassurances and guarantees that contradict or change what was agreed back in November.”  Admitting he had “given up speculating at this stage” on potential Brexit outcomes, he said it was a problem triggered by the UK. “We’re really looking to them for a solution,” he said. “It’s up to them to make a proposal but it has to be a proposal that we can accept. “It can’t be a proposal that contradicts what’s already in the withdrawal agreement. “It can’t be something that renders the backstop inoperable.” Mr Dodds warned his party would not support the current plan. He said: “The backstop is not the best of both worlds. “It is potentially indefinite in time, would place a barrier between us and our main trading partner in Great Britain and give enormous leverage to the EU in negotiations on the future relationship with the UK. “We will have further discussions with the Prime Minister and will continue to work with the government is interests of getting a better deal.”

title: what its like live 60
story: NewsWhat its like to live on £ a week under the governments miners pension schemeMore than £.billion has been taken out of the Mineworkers Pension Scheme - while former colliers live on as little as £ a week. Reporter Anna Lewis heard their storiesShareCommentsByAnna Lewis:,  JAN NewsKen Sullivan says his pension is only half of what it should be "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMen who once toiled down pits have been forced to give up their homes.Families who must meticulously count their pennies to make ends meet. This is the situation thousands of former miners and colliers found themselves in when, after years of back-breaking work, they were finally able to retire. Now three former colliers have spoken of the reality of living on as little as pound per week from the miners pension scheme in moving testimony, originally published by WalesOnline. In recent years the terms of the Mineworkers Pension Scheme have come under growing criticism by those who were working underground when it was decided in . Since then the government have taken more than pound. billion in surpluses out of the same pot - and will take pound million more over the next three years. Unbeknown to many, the situation with the Mineworkers Pension Scheme began  years ago when British Coal was privatised.  At the time, ministers agreed the Government would act as guarantor for two pension schemes - The Mineworkers Pension Scheme, boasting , members, and the British Coal Staff Superannuation Scheme, with , members. Under the deal, any surplus money gained from the scheme would be split   between the Treasury and scheme members. But, while it was estimated the funds would generate a pound billion surplus over  years, it has done better than expected. In November, energy minister Claire Perry revealed pound million had been taken by the Treasury in  alone. In total, the Mineworker Pension Fight claims the amount taken by the Government has reached pound billion in just over  years - while former workers receive an average pension of pound a week. At -years-old Emlyn Davies lives with his daughter and her husband. He is one of the surviving , former miners who paid .% into the scheme while working.  While the decision was made after his we Gwynneths death in , the pensioner claims he would not be able to afford to live on his own. This is because, after  years working in Penrhiwceiber Colliery he now receives pound a week. I receive pound a week. Imagine playing pound or pound a week in and you only have pound back after  years , Emlyn, known to family and friends as Em, said. When I was a young man - I started in the s - we thought we would have a good pension. Then they altered it and I thought it would be even better but it ended up not being the case. We are still poor. At -years-old, Em followed the footsteps of his father and two older brothers to begin a career in the colliery. Originally a worker on the coal face, he later moved to work with the power loading machinery. As a working father-of-five le was hard - but there were plenty of happy times. He said: When the kids were very young I was still in the pit and we had everything they wanted for Christmas.  We used to go in debt for six months after to back out of it. Thats why our family are so close - we gave them everything and they seem to share that. It wasnt a lot but we lived day to day. However, for the grandfather-of- and great-grandfather-of-, things changed once he hit retirement age. He said: After I retired all together it was a struggle. We couldnt live on the money we were given, every year we would go to the bank and borrow pound, with interest and everything. Thats why we decided to sell the house and move into council rented accommodation. We lost our house - we had to sell it because we couldnt afford the repairs. Now Ive got a good family around me and my daughter and her husband have taken me on. After I lost my we I took it badly. ButI was living on my own now I wouldnt be able to survive. At -years-old, former Oakdale colliery worker Ken Sullivan took the decision to retire after undergoing triple bypass surgery. His career in the colliery also started at the age of  when he began to support his father who was a prisoner of war during World War Two. Now, he receives pound a week from the scheme, alongside his state pension. Ken, who has lived in the same house in Tredegar since he was born, said: People think it is a good amount but when you contemplate what you have paid in its not that much. My we budgets everything down to the last penny. Theres only certain things we can buy and certain things we cant but you get used to it. We dont go out - my we last went out three years ago. For the -year-old, the hardest part is not being able to take his whole family on holiday each year. He said: With Christmas we make sure we have a good time and are not going without but there are one or two extra things we cant get. Im only getting half the pension I should - an extra pound would make a huge dference. For Ken, reality hit home this winter home while watching BBC drama Care - which charted the dficulties of a woman who develops dementia after a stroke. Ken said: Its frightening to think what could become of you. Before we get to that stage it would be nice to enjoy le without worrying about every penny. Two years ago, the father and grandfather began a petition calling for the scheme to be reviewed. It now has more than , signatures. As part of his campaigning, Ken has visited every village and town in South Wales drumming up support - and has met those in situations far worse than his own. He said: In Abertillery there was an old lady and she was told she would get pound. a week as a widower. Her husband would have got pound a week. She was gutted and thought the pension was disgusting but accepted what she had. A lot of people dont realise what has taken place. What we are asking for is the pension we have paid into. We are not asking for charity, we are not asking for hand-outs, thats all we want. Between  and , Gareth Davies also worked at Oakdale Colliery. Gareth, , is thankful his situation is better than most thanks to his pound-a-month pension - arranged due to his position as collier official. Gareth, who now lives in Aberdare, said: I receive pound a month but there are many more that are on a lot less. I have heard many many sad stories, there are people that havent got a penny. I have spoken to people that have teared-up speaking about it. Ive recently separated from my we so Im living on my own and Ive got debts to pay off so its not easy. He added: The government took over our pension scheme under dubious circumstances. The ones worst off are those that left school at  and expected to retire at . Their funds have been used by the government to pay out the banks. A Government spokesman said: “The Mineworkers’ Pensions Scheme is subject to a Government Guarantee which ensures that a member’s pension, including inflation increases, will always be paid. “Members have received pensions approximately % larger than would have been the case without the Guarantee.”

title: chris packham offers himself human
story: NewsChris Packham offers himself as human prey to stop foxes being torn to piecesThe BBC Springwatch presenter says its time we put an end to fox hunting once and for all - and has offered himself as quarry for the New Forest Hounds in HampshireShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video chris-packham-end-fox-hunting-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn a bid to stop foxes being torn to pieces, animal campaigner Chris Packham offered himself as a hunts first human quarry. The naturalist urged his local hunt in Hampshire, the New Forest Hounds, to switch to drag hunting, which involves dog tracking either a human runner or chemical scent. He says their trail hunting can still end with foxes being killed. Hunts in some parts of the UK have faced allegations the blood sport has continued under the guise of trail hunting. Chris , visited the hunt at Linwood, near Ringwood, Hants, on New Years Day and made a short film about how there is no place for it in st century Britain. In the video, he spoke generally about fox hunting in the UK. There is nothing to suggest the New Forest Hounds did anything illegal.He said: Animals are still being hunted, torn to pieces by packs of dogs in the st century. I know it’s dficult to get your head around that, we work so hard with conservation. and here we are standing in a National Park, a place where millions of people come to enjoy the countryside and it’s wildle.  And yet others are out there tearing it to pieces with dogs. We’ve got to put an end to it. Please join me in  to work harder than ever before to put an end to this horrible anachronism. Theres no place for this savagery in st century Britain. The clip was viewed over , times and shared by over ,. And despite his offer to be the hunts first human quarry, the -year-old hunt group declined, saying it would be impractical for their dogs. Labour outlawed hunting foxes with dogs in , causing NFH and other hunts to turn to trail hunting in which hounds chase an articial scent, but critics believe the sport can still result in hunts chasing a fox accidentally or deliberately. Chris added: Fox hunting is a highly emotive activity which has no place in the contemporary environment - and everyone knows that. The law is constantly contravened. Foxes are being torn to pieces in peoples front gardens and pets are being chased.  We have to make peaceful, democratic progress in ending this practice. Its very dficult to monitor fox hunting and its also very dficult when things go wrong to get a successful prosecution.Police are under-resourced and have many other things to deal with. If hunts switched to drag hunting it would have a positive impact in public relations terms as well as having a positive impact on wildle. Im not saying its the whole answer but it would be a step in the right direction. If the New Forest Hounds did that, I would be happy to be their first human quarry. A New Forest Hounds spokesman today said it would be dficult to switch to drag hunting. He said: We thank Chris Packham for his offer of being hunted by the New Forest Hounds but we dont think it would be practical. We spent a lot of time and effort in getting our hounds to switch to trail hunting. We think it would be even more dficult, perhaps even impossible, to get them to switch to drag hunting. It would go against  years of breeding. Chris Pitt, deputy director of campaigns at the League Against Cruel Sports, added: Wild animals, including foxes, hare and deer, are still being chased to exhaustion before being torn to pieces. There is strong support for British wildle being given robust protection from those who kill for sport How can we call ourselves a civilised nation when those who gain entertainment from attacking wildle continue to go unpunished by the law  You can sign a petition supported by Chris here.

title: could tiny one bedroom pop
story: NewsCould these tiny one-bedroom pop-up homes solve Britains housing crisis Plans for a miniature Snug box home in a Bristol garden have been approvedShareCommentsByAmanda Cameron:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsEach home will have its own little grassy space "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTiny pop-up homes could be rolled out across an English city in a bid to solve the its housing crisis. Currently Bristol City Councils planning policy does not allow the building new single-occupier homes. This is because the local authority recommends that at least two bed spaces should be made available and room for additional visitors in every new property.However, proposals for three tiny one-bed, one-person homes in the Hillfields area have recently been approved. An existing two-story Victorian building will be ided into two flats. And a new pop-up Snug home will be created in the rear garden of an existing house.At sqm to sqm, the ground-floor flat, first-floor flat and prefabricated box house all meet or exceed minimum internal floor space requirements under UK housing standards.  Each home will have its own little grassy space, and two of them will have a small patio as well. And while only one new Snug house has been approved so far, it could lead to the roll out of future homes. Planning committee members approved the new homes after developer Ecomotive urged them to “stand up and make new precedents” to help solve Bristol’s housing crisis. But council officers had recommended that councillors reject the plans, arguing that the proposed one-person homes do not provide enough room for everyday activities. An officer said: “Bristol does not accept one-bed spaces because they cannot accommodate extra residents should the need arise. “Bristol City Council expects that all new dwellings provide at least two bed spaces. “It is considered that this is the smallest unit size that can meet the flexibility and adaptability of the policies outlined, i.e., accommodate sufficient space for a partner, a child, temporary carer or visiting friends or relatives.” But Michelle Asher from Ecomotive, which is developing the Snug home design, disagreed. She said: “I’d hate to see Bristol City Council turn down a totally viable living option which addresses the need for affordable housing, small footprints, enough space for people to live comfortably and with dignity and the right to choose just based on limiting bureaucratic regulations.”  The council’s development manager, Gary Collins, advised councillors to change local planning policynecessary rather than make a habit of overruling it. Councillors backed the house conversion by nine votes to two before unanimously approving the “Snug” prefab home in the rear garden. The planning report reads: The dwelling itself is proposed to be a two storey,  bedroom,  bed space dwelling with an overall gross internal floor area of approximately sqm, ided over its two storeys. The dwelling would be .m in height and adopt a modern box   SNUG home design with a flat roof. Amenity space would be provided through a small patio areato the rear of the proposed dwelling and an area of grassachieved through the subision of the existing garden at  Forest Road. No members of the public had objected to either application and  wrote in support of the prefab home. Mr Collins added that the council is developing a new policy approach to modular units.

story: NewsFamilys New Years resolution after son was beaten so badly he had legs amputatedEXCLUSIVE: Little Tony Hudgells adoptive parents, Paula and Mark, are pushing to increase the maximum prison sentence a court can give to perpetrators of child crueltyShareCommentsByLiz Dunphy:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsLittle Tony Hudgell beams with his mum, Paula Hudgell, as they enjoy a day out in Winter Wonderland, Hyde Park "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLittle Tony Hudgell beams and squeals with delight as he glides down a giant ice slide on his big brothers knee. The adventurous four-year-old would probably try to tackle the slide in Winter Wonderland on his own but both his legs were amputated after he was abused by his birth parents when he was just weeks old. His birth parents were later jailed thanks to the tireless work of Tonys adoptive parents, Paula and Mark Hudgell, who pushed to have them prosecuted after the Crown Prosecution Serviceinitially dropped the case.  The family of  took a trip to Winter Wonderland in Hyde Park, London, to celebrate the New Year. Paula said: Winter Wonderland was magical. Tony particularly loved the Ice Kingdom which was like walking into a giant freezer with lots of ice sculptures everywhere. He went down the ice slide on his brothers, Jaden and Henrys, laps. And his face lit up when he watched Peter Pan on Ice which he loved. He was sitting right at the front.  Four years ago, little Tonys le was effectively saved by Christmas. The baby was admitted to hospital with multiple organ failure, numerous fractures and sepsis. After a six week battle to save him, doctors made the dficult decision just before Christmas, , to withdraw all but palliative care. But in an extraordinary twist of fate, doctors were unable to stop treatment because Tony was a ward of court – and the courts had closed for Christmas. Those few days gave him the chance to fight for his le and he amazed doctors by rallying. Weeks later, he was fostered by the Hudgells and his le took a dramatic turn for the better.  Now Christmas is an extra-special time for the whole family. Paula said: Tony was so excited for Christmas. He said it was his best day ever. He loved it all. Santa brought him lots of presents and he loved being with the whole family. Now having celebrated a wonderful Christmas together Paula has said that her New Year resolution is to continue to fight for vulnerable children and to build more protection for children into British law. The resolute mum-of-eight from Kent started a petition calling for tougher sentences for child cruelty and quickly collected more than , signatures of support. Her MP, Tom Tugendhat, will present the petition to the House of Commons on January, , and together they hope to change the law in baby Tonys name.  Paula said: This year I will continue to fight for all children until we get tougher sentences for anyone who hurts them. Increased sentences will make no dference to Tony now but hopefully it will help future children.  Too many children are abused and neglected and something needs to be done to stop that. Despite Tonys horric start in le, he has been thriving under the Hudgells care, changing from a broken little boy to a confident, smiling child with big brown eyes that just melt your heart, Paula, , said.  Nothing stops him now. Hes really fast getting around and hes caught up cognitively with all his peers. He is a very determined little boy.”  Paula added: He has been through so much but hes such a wonderful little boy. He shows that all so many children need is a little bit of love and care. Now my children say Tony is their inspiration, their hero. Tony has changed us all. I would never have had the confidence before to push parliament to change the law before. title: former army cadet enormous 5lb
story: NewsHorried mum vomits poo and has bowels and anus removed due to enormous herniaWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGES: Tanya Evans, , of Swansea, South Wales, turned yellow and suffered years of painShareCommentsByErin Cardf:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe mum suffered years of pain "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former Army cadet has suffered from a lb hernia so heavy, it would slap against her thighs and leave bruises. Tanya Evans, , was living in agony for years after the mysterious growth appeared out of the blue one day in . However she postponed surgery while she desperately tried for a baby with her fiance Mark Jenkins, . Just as she was giving up hope Tanya fell pregnant with Josie, who was born in December . Since then she has had a major operation in April  to remove the bowel - which was pushing through her abdominal wall causing the hernia. Her rectum and anus had also been irreparably damaged following a prolapse and she is still battling with daily pain.  Tanya, of Swansea, South Wales, said: “I still struggle every day, with the simplest of tasks. “Mark has to help me shower and I can barely lt anything. That means I can’t pick Josie up for a cuddle, which is heartbreaking. “She’s too young to understand, so she thinks it’s because she’s been naughty. The physical side of things has been hard, but the mental has been absolute torture.” Tanyas nightmare began back in , when she was raced to hospital with a severe bowel obstruction. Gravely ill, her skin turned yellow and she even vomited up faeces. She explained: “I was vomiting up something black, which tasted disgusting. Medics tested it and told me it was faeces. I was absolutely terried.”  Forced to have an ileostomy, where the small bowel, or intestine, is erted through an opening in the abdomen, Tanya was left with a stoma bag. Its designed to collect waste that would ordinarily be passing through the large intestine and out of the body. Despite a few weeks of colic – abdominal pain – she felt relatively well, and was hopeful she would make a full recovery. But one day later in , a hernia appeared. According to the NHS,it occurs when an internal part of the body, in Tanya’s case her bowel, pushes through a weakness in the muscle or surrounding wall. She said: “I had it checked over, and confirmed as a hernia. At first, I was reassured it could be easily sorted out – but then, I also began to bleed from my bottom.” Further investigations revealed that Tanya was suffering from ersion colitis, and inflammation of the colon, which can occur as a complication of surgery.  Given pain medication as well as steroid enemas to calm the inflammation, she faced another knockback when she realised that surgery to remove the growth could cause fertility issues. Doctors warned that,the womb was affected too, a hysterectomy may be necessary. With a waiting list for the procedure anyway, doctors agreed she should take the chance to try for a baby while she could. “Mark and I tried and tried and I cried at every negative test,” she said. “I started to fear it would never happen for us, but then, we conceived. “Josie was born on December ,  three weeks early, weighing lb oz. She had to be delivered via caesarean, due to the hernia, but she was happy and healthy.” After recovering from childbirth, Tanya met with a team of medics, and her surgery was pencilled in for August . She continued: “But then August came and went, then September, then October. I was told there were no beds available, which I understand happens, but what was I supposed to do  I felt like I was dying. “Then, at the end of the year, I discovered the surgeon who was meant to be doing my operation was retiring, so no longer available. I was terried I’d be back at square one, on another wait list to see another doctor.  “I contacted the patient liaison department and they kept asking what they could do to help. But all anyone could do was wait for a cancellation to come up. So, I fought and fought.” As she waited, Tanya’s hernia continued to grow, eventually reaching lb. She added: “It affected everything I did, and put so much pressure on my body. Sitting down hurt, standing up hurt – everything. “It even bruised my legs where it’d bang against my thigh. At its worst, it would twist and strangulate, where the blood supply to the intestines and abdominal tissues gets cut off.” Eventually, in April , Tanya went under the kne. Though she did not have a hysterectomy, surgeons did remove her bowel, rectum and anus, which had been damaged by a prolapse – where organs fall down, or slip out of place. Adding that, since the hernia was removed, she has gone from a size  to a , she continued: “Apparently, where the strangulated hernia had cut off the blood supply, my bowel was just completely dead, and the tissue was virtually disintegrated.  “Once they saw the damage that’d been going on inside, medics couldn’t believe I’d been walking around. “It’s not that I have a high pain threshold, though. I’ve just become used to the pain, which is very sad.” When she first came round, Tanya admitted she could not bear to look at her scar, which she said resembled a shark bite. Now, still wearing a bag attached to her stoma to collect waste, she is hoping to also have tummy tuck surgery to remove the baggy skin where it was stretched over the hernia. With a hysterectomy still a consideration in the future, depending on how her regular check ups go, she said: “When people hear tummy tuck, they assume it’s because I want to look good.But it’s actually because I have been left with saggy skin, that can hang down and make my bag leak. “Le is very dferent for me now. I have to be incredibly careful just moving around, as one awkward fall could split my stitching and hospitalise me. I still sit on an air cushion every day, too, as sitting down without is simply too painful. “I don’t want anybody  to go through this, so I am urging others out there to keep pushing and fighting for helpthey need it.”  Jo Davies, Assistant Service Group Manager, Surgical Specialties for Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board, which covers Swansea, said: In line with other health boards in Wales, we continue to experience signicant challenges in providing routine urgent elective surgery.We are taking ongoing action to reduce theof time patients are waiting for surgery. This includes the appointment of new consultant surgeons, the outsourcing of appropriate patients to private hospitals, and additional theatre sessions. Waiting lists are also reviewed weekly to ensure patients with the highest clinical needs are given priority. Ms Evans did not meet the clinical criteria for outsourcing and required an inpatient bed in one of our hospitals. However, as always, we have to give priority to patients with le limb-threatening conditions, cancer and trauma patients. Unfortunately as a result of this we were unable to offer Ms Evans an earlier date, though we are very pleased her surgery went ahead earlier this year.

title: important thing you must stop
story: NewsImportant thing you must do to stop norovirus spreading - evenyou feel betterNorovirus has been reported across the UK - heres what you can do to help stop it spreadingShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe virus is very unpleasant "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Brits across the UK have been struck down with norovirus - the unpleasant bug that leaves people miserable in bed for days. The Mirror reported that people around the country were bedridden over the festive period, taking to social media to vent about their misery because of the vile bug - with some even asking neighbours to help them as they were so ill.Symptoms are nasty, and typically include nausea, vomiting, fever, diarrhoea, headaches, achy arms and legs. These symptoms normally start a couple of days after being infected, and fortunately most people feel better in around two days. But evenyou feel OK enough to go about your day as usual, you should stay at home for a bit longer - heres why. According to the NHS website , you should stay off work or school after symptoms have stopped for two days , as this is when you are most contagious.Going back to work or taking your child back school when still poorly means classmates and colleagues could get the unpleasant bug too - which nobody will thank you for. The virus spreads very easily, through close contact, touching surfaces that have the virus on then touching your mouth, or eating food prepared by someone with the virus. The NHS also recommends avoiding visiting anyone in hospital during this time. Once you do leave the house again, making sure you wash your hands regularly and use hand sanitiser is still important. If youre still in the throes of feeling miserable with norovirus, you can ease symptoms by drinking plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration, eating plain foods , taking paracetamol for aches and getting lots of rest. You normally dont need to see a GPyou have norovirus, as antibiotics wont help and you may spread the bug.Get medical advice :Symptoms persist for more than several days Your child is severely dehydrated Your baby or child is less responsive, feverish, or has pale or mottled skin Your baby or child has passed  or more watery stools in the past  hours, or has vomited  times or more in the past  hours Call NHS youre concerned or feel you need advice.

story: NewsMum of girl, , whose throat was slit shares tragic photo of her final ChristmasKatie Rough was smothered before her throat was cut by a -year-old killer less than one mile from her home in YorkShareByLiz Dunphy:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAlison Rough shared a photo of a wide-eyed Katie opening presents on her very last Christmas "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKatie Roughs mum has shared a photo of her precious daughters last Christmas - taken two weeks before she was smothered and her throat was slit while playing in a field near their home. A wide-eyed Katie turns to face the camera while opening presents in what would be one of the last photos ever taken of her alive. Under the image, her heartbroken mum, Alison Rough, wrote: This was her very last Christmas. We spoilt her rotten. Im so glad we did. I could never say no to her xxx. Katie was just seven-years-old when a neighbour found her leless and bleeding, lying on the grass in a playing field less than one mile from her home in York, on January, , .  She had been smothered with a glove before her killer used a Stanley kne to make a cm slash to her neck and a cm wound to her torso, which cut through fat, skin and muscle, prosecutors said at the trial at Leeds Crown Court in . Katie’s mum Alison, then , raced to the scene and dropped to her knees screaming: “No, no, my little girl,” before trying to cradle her head. Katie was rushed to hospital but was pronounced dead shortly afterwards.  A teenage girl, who Katie had been playing with before her death, was found covered in blood in a nearby cul-de-sac, clutching a kne while calling  to admit to the killing. She was later charged with manslaughter and jailed for le. The death of the little girl, who had been a bridesmaid at her parents wedding just two weeks earlier, sent shock-waves through the community. The disturbed girl who killed her was -years-old at the time and she cannot be named for legal reasons. She pleaded guilty to Katies manslaughter by diminished responsibility, but not guilty to murder.  Mr Justice Soole, who presided over the trial, said that the defendant posed a high risk of serious harm to others and to yourself before sentencing her. He said it was a truly exceptional case and ordered her to be detained for a minimum of five years. In the months before the attack, Katies killer had expressed disturbing thoughts - from grisly dreams and acts of self harm to the mutilation of a toy. She lost most of her school friends and developed an interest in the macabre as her mental health deteriorated ahead of the pre-planned killing.  Often very upset, the teenager experienced delusional and bizarre thoughts, the court heard during her trial. She became convinced that people around her werent human and were robots. She also dreamed of killing someone and reported hearing voices inside her head, according to one friend, who described the teenager as nice but weird.  She had been taken out of school due to the severity of her mental health problems and was under the care of a mental health team. The girls mental health issues escalated over the course of more than a year until, in January, she smothered Katie on the playing field and then slashed at her body. Post-mortem results showed Katie died from asphyxiation, with her wounds inflicted after her death. Pathologists found that a gloved hand was held over her face to suffocate her before she had her neck and torso slashed.

title: mum shunned friends family after
story: NewsMum shunned by friends and family after dating again eight weeks after husband diesNatalie Drury, , from Greater Manchester went on to meet her new partner, Paul, through a dating website a year after her husband diedShareCommentsBySophie Norris:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNatalie Drury, , with late husband Tim Madeley "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA widowed mum claims she was shunned by friends and family members because she began dating eight weeks after her husband died Natalie Drurys husband Tim Madeley, , passed away on New Years Day , following a short battle with brain cancer. Eight weeks later, the -year-old nursery cook went on her first date since he died. Although it didnt progress into a relationship, Natalie claims the criticism she faced then and still faces today has been devastating. Despite receiving support from most of her family, Natalie said that she had a hard time from friends and family - especially those on Tims side. Now happily married for the second time after finding love online, Natalie is speaking to encourage others to stop being so judgemental about love after berevement. Natalie, from Stalybridge, Greater Manchester, said: When Tim took ill in the August, they told me pretty early on what the outcome was going to be. I did my grieving in those four months while he was still here. I knew what was coming and I had to stay strong for our son Oliver.  When Tim died, my friends didnt call because they didnt know what to say, so they didnt say anything at all. I was in shock and so lonely. Eventually I got to the point where I did want to go out and so I went on a date with a local man. It didnt go anywhere but it caused people to say I had disrespected my husband. I had every respect for him - but I knew he was never coming back. I couldnt sit alone in my house crying. I went out and enjoyed myself for a few weeks. People avoid you when a loved one dies. Soon after Tim passed away I was walking down the street and people would cross over because they didnt know what to say. You do feel isolated. If you havent been through it you can never understand. [Finding love again] doesnt mean Ive no respect for Tim. Some people were judgemental, especially at work. I had got a job after he passed. People would say its only been two years but Id say exactly. Do you want me to sit on the sofa wearing black and never go out  People are so quick to judge. Its not right. In the summer prior to his death, Tim and Natalie had been on holiday to Spain with their four-year-old son Oliver while Tim did some painting work.  The couple were away for a week but days into the trip, Natalie noticed her husband was behaving really weird and had been acting daft. A desperate Natalie even called her dad saying she wanted to come home and when the family ed to the UK, Tim visited the doctors. Natalie said: We went on holiday in  to Spain which is when Tim started behaving really weird. Hed be walking with his head on the side orI gave him his lunch on a plate, hed look at me and tip it all on the floor. Wed gone over there because hed agreed to do some work on a villa.  As the week went on, he hadnt done any painting and was just behaving really daft. I began to notice something wasnt right. When we got back, I took him straight to the doctors and they thought hed had a stroke. He went into hospital that night and he was soon diagnosed with a brain tumour. The specialists said that because wed been on holiday the air pressure on the plane had accelerated the tumour. He went to The Christie in Manchester but there was nothing they could do. They gave him chemotherapy but it wasnt doing anything at all. I did mourn. From getting the brain tumour, each of the words that came out Tims mouth you couldnt take seriously. It was like talking to an older person with dementia. He wanted me to be happy and move on.  That December, Natalie scrambled around to afford Christmas presents for Oliver as her husband lay in his hospice bed. During what should have been a happy time of year, she agonised over how to tell her little boy that his dad might not make it through the month. Natalie said: It was horrendous, especially during that Christmas. I was trying to keep things jolly for Oliver but I was struggling for money. Sadly Tim was soon transferred to a hospice. He couldnt speak or move around. It was just terrible. Oliver understood what was happening. He asked me is my daddy going to die . I could have lied and said no. But I sat him down and explained in terms a four-year-old would be able to understand. Tim had been the breadwinner and Id been at home with Oliver, so people rallied round us to make sure he got some Christmas presents. Tim survived through Christmas but the week later he went downhill. On New Years Day  he passed away.  Suffering with the crippling loneliness and grief, Natalie decided to begin dating again just eight weeks later. However when her first dates didnt come to anything, she focused on helping her son Oliver come to terms with losing his dad. By , Natalie decided to get out there once again and started dating again. Although it was almost two years since Tim had died, Natalie claims she was still judged by family and colleagues - even after her she married Paul  months later. Natalie said: At the end of  I joined Plenty of Fish and thats where I met Paul. It was a happy ending. Paul is a lovely man and from the start I told him the whole story. I explained I had a son and he might be sensitive to the situation, but Oliver took to him straight away. It just progressed from there and soon it became our new normal. When we got married it was really sweet.  At the wedding reception looked up at us and said can I play out  He ran over to Paul and said Daddy, can we play out . Oliver still talks about Tim. He has his watch and we speak about him everyday - night and day. Oliver is now eight years old. A lot of people, especially family, we dont speak to. Tim had older children - he was  years older than me. He had five, including Oliver. Im still in contact with two of them now. They were really supportive from the beginning and came to my wedding in the evening. [Some other people on Tims side of the family were] really unsupportive and quite disrespectful. When Natalie got a new job as a nursery cook, she was also questioned about how quickly she had found a new partner. Despite losing some friends and family, Natalie claimed her own family were there for her and believes Oliver was helped by seeing her smile again. Natalie said: I just feel like [those that criticised me about starting to date again] need to take a step back and think. God forbidthey were in that position. You just cant say that. I did join Plenty of Fish but I didnt go out looking for love. I still post about him. I posted on Facebook on New Years Day last year its been nearly three years since you passed and I hope that youre looking down on me on my wedding day. I got a lot of comments - none to my face. My family were so supportive. I think its helped Oliver to see his mum happy again.

story: NewsRubbish collections reduced to ONCE a month force Brits to pay for private binmenEXCLUSIVE: Hundreds of homes have been left with bulging bins over Christmas and New Year because of the once-monthly trial schemes - which could be rolled out across the UKShareCommentsByPaul Byrne:,  JAN NewsNeill Scullard, from North Wales, has been forced to pay for private binmen "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of homes have been left with bulging bins over Christmas and New Year because of once-a-month collections. Residents, fearing the health risks of an infestation of rats, have had to make repeated visits to the tip to dump their rubbish. Some have had to resort to using private firms to take away the waste. Now there are serious concerns that once-monthly trial schemes could be rolled out across the UK. In September, Conwy in North Wales became the first council in England and Wales to start emptying bins only every four weeks, hoping to save some pound, a year.   Local Neill Scullard said his general waste bin was picked up on the Friday before Christmas and will not be collected again until January . He said: “The black bin for non-recyclable waste is the real problem – the waste has been piling up. “You can see tears in the plastic where the rats have been. Where there is rubbish, there will be rats.” The dad-of-two, from Penmaenmawr, near Conwy, added: “By the time the next collection comes, the bins will be horric. I’ve already done three trips to the tip. “We have been paying pound more council tax this year for less services.”   Chef Neill, , has three green recycling boxes, for plastic and cans, one for cardboard and glass, and one for paper. These are emptied fortnightly. He has a food-waste bin and a nappy bin, both tended to weekly. But it is the once-a-month general waste that is the issue. Some families have reportedly paid up pound a year to private firms who provide weekly collections.   But Conwy County Borough Council claim that for the majority of people “four-weekly bin collections are no problem”. It says a two-year trial scheme saw a % increase in recycling rates and added it has Welsh Government target to meet by  . Neighbouring Denbighshire County Council plan monthly collections in  and nearby Anglesey is also considering the switch.Today is known as ‘fly-tipping Friday’ – the worst day of the year for illegal dumping of waste.

title: when christmas decorations come down
story: NewsWhen you should take Christmas decorations down - and its to do with Twelfth NightDecking the house in Christmas decorations is a central part of the festive season, but as Epiphany approaches it is time to take them downShareCommentsByRoz LawsLaura NightingaleJo-Anne Rowney:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video should-you-take-your-christmas-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNothing gets you in the festive mood more than the Christmas tree in the corner of a room, festooned with twinkly lights and an array of baubles. But as  dawns and its time to go back to school and work, the sagging branches are looking a bit sad and rooms are feeling just a bit too crammed full. Theres probably more pine needles on the floor than on the lower boughs, and that traditional Christmas tree smell has all but faded. You may have already taken them down, but the tradition, since the Victorian era, is to remove decorations on Twelfth Night. Every year this very tradition causes confusion, as people are left scratching their heads wondering when the date falls and why. Heres the answers and the date when you should take down your decorations. When is Twelfth Night   Depending on what youre celebrating its either January  or January  - and the last day you should keep festive decorations up. A day sooner or later is considered unlucky anddecorations are not removed on Twelfth Night then according to tradition they should stay up all year. Until the th century though, people would keep their decorations up until Candlemas Day on February . Twelfth Night falls on January  and Epiphany on January . Twelfth Night is so called because traditionally Christmas was a  day celebration, beginning on December . This can create some confusion as some will class January  as Twelfth Night because it is the th day after Christmas. Epiphany marks the end of Christmas when the Three Kings came to visit bearing gts, guided by the star which is now represented in the twinkling lights adorning our homes. Why is it unlucky   January  is observed as the last day of Christmas festivities - the eve of the Epiphany. In the past it was believed that tree-spirits lived in the greenery – such as holly and ivy – that people used to decorate their homes. While the festive season provided shelter for these spirits during the winter, they needed to be released outside once Christmas was over. If this custom wasn’t followed, greenery would notand vegetation would not grow as a result, causing agricultural and then food problems. Even though Christmas decorations are now less about foliage and more about baubles, glitter, tinsel and singing Santas, many people still adhere to the superstition. Do all countries follow this tradition   No. Because there is disagreement as to whether January  or January  is actually Twelfth Night lots of countries end up taking down their festooned trees at dferent times. This can also depend on when people actually celebrate the festive season - for example in Russia Christmas Day falls on January . But January  is officially the day of the Epiphany. This is from the Christian tradition where the faithful mark the birth of Jesus on December . The Maji didnt arrive until much later with their gtsso Christians mark this on January . Children were traditionally told thatyou took down your decorations before the Eve of the Epiphany, the wise men might not be able to find their way - because Christmas lights represent the Star of Bethlehem which guided them to Jesus. A number of countries in Europe follow the January  tradition, including the Germans, Poles and Czechs. However for some people, simply having the decorations up into the New Year is too much and many will be taking them down on the st of January.  Real Christmas trees will be accepted at most household tips, but local authorities, garden centres and community groups may accept them for recycling. Find out where might be suitable for this in your area.  If your decorations aren’t going into a loft or attic, make sure they’re stored in a watertight, plastic box - in fact, doing this wherever they are kept will protect them from damp and pests. It’s also worth wrapping fragile Christmas ornaments in tissue paper before storage - and, of course, coiling the lights in a neat circle round your arm. Obviously the loft fairies will have tangled them into a mess by next December, but at least you can say you tried when you open them in a frazzled temper next time.  The UK is estimated to use almost , tonnes of card packaging at Christmas, enough to make a cardboard motorway stretching from Birmingham to Lapland and back  times. Recycle Now is urging consumers to recycle this material rather than bin it. Shiny and metallic ieties of wrapping paper are not recyclable, so the campaign advises people to use the ‘scrunch test’ to check. If you scrunch the paper in your hand and it stays in a ball then it can by recycled but it can’tthe paper springs back. If youre recycling bin is full, several shops such as Marks and Spencer run card recycling schemes to raise funds for charity. For every , cards dropped in to MS stores in January, a tree is planted by the Woodland Trust . Last year  million cards were collected and , trees planted.

title: bottom of table dundee need some guts says martin woods
story: Midfielder Martin Woods expects Dundee boss Jim McIntyre to put together a team of fighters this month that the Dens Park faithful can get behind as they stare a drop battle in the face.The -year-old, who is expected to extend his short-term deal with the club, was part of the Ross County rebuild job done by the current Dark Blues gaffer back in -.McIntyre’s new-look side kept the club in the top-flight and Woods is backing his boss to repeat that feat.By the end of January,  new players had come in with nine departing Dingwall before embarking on a epic run of eight wins and a draw from nine games between February and the end-of-season split – with Woods kicking off the run with an opener against Motherwell on Valentine’s Day.He said: “There’s no hiding that the gaffer wants to make a lot changes, get people in he can trust and that know the style of play he wants.“The previous manager recruited in a certain way and it doesn’t suit the current manager, so I expect a lot of changes and we’ll be a lot stronger team come the end of January.“January was huge for us at Ross County, we found a team and went on a crazy run.“It was really, really good but it’s a tough league and the players who come in have to hit the ground running.“They need to have the right character and the manager will be looking to do that with his recruitment.“It doesn’t always click straight away but that’s why the manager will be looking for certain types, for people who are reliable.”The Dark Blues finished off a dreadful year with a woeful performance in a - home defeat to St Johnstone on Saturday which only made the need for a raft of changes to the squad clearer to see.Woods added: “When the chips were down on Saturday it wasn’t good enough, it was poor, lacking energy, lacking bravery. Bringing in the right people who have been there and done it, have got the drive to take the ball and make something happen and can make the flash that gets us back into the game will make us a lot stronger.”Woods has made a real impact on the side since penning a short-term contract that expired after the weekend loss.Even in that defeat, the former Partick man drew the only positive shout from the crowd as he squared up to a couple of St Johnstone men with the yell ‘at least he’s showing a bit of fight’ coming from the home support.“I would agree with that,” Woods said.“That was out of pure frustration. The crowd in the main have been absolutely brilliant and that’s just not me trying to be the good guy and get everybody up.“I think they’ve been really good for the position the club is in.“They just want people battling, people at it, giving their lot – that’s the least you should be giving. I think those will be the types the manager is after in January, giving what he is like as a guy and what he demands of people.“He’ll want people to go and give their lot, it might not be perfect every week, but they’ll give their full lot and they’ll have some guts.”Though he’s not signed yet till the end of the season, Woods says he’s keen to stay on.He added: “We spoke after the game and that’s ongoing just now, we’ll see what happens.“I’ve loved my time here, the fans have been great with me, the boys have been great, too, getting me right in the mix straight away.“The manager has been really good, I know what I’m getting from him but I think he needs a bit of help so, hopefully, he gets that this month and gets a few boys in who are up for the challenge.”

title: dundee set to make sensational move for dundee united striker craig curran
story: Dundee United striker Craig Curran could be set for a sensational crossing of Sandeman Street with Dundee boss Jim McIntyre keen to add him to his striking options.Curran was signed by the Dens gaffer at Ross County and, with the Dark Blues in a similar position to the one the Staggies were in back in , McIntyre wants the -year-old to aid veteran Kenny Miller in the striking stakes.The Liverpudlian scored  times over four seasons for the Highland outfit but still has two-and-a-half years on his deal at Tannadice.A step back up to the Premiership to play for his old gaffer might just suit him, evenit means making the switch between city clubs.Meanwhile, Glen Kamara may have played his last game for Dundee with a raft of clubs lining up to look at the Finnish international.English Premier League battlers Cardf City are the latest to have looked at the central midfielder with boss Neil Warnock admitting this week he’s interested in Kamara.The Tele revealed last month that fellow-Welsh side Swansea City had sent scouts to run the rule over the former Arsenal kid.And in the summer he’d also been linked with both Celtic and Rangers, Hearts and Hibs, as well as English Championship clubs including Frank Lampard’s Derby County.With his contract ending at the end of the season, the -year-old can speak to other clubs regarding a pre-contract move.However, the playing style under new manager McIntyre isn’t suited to the former Arsenal man’s talents and a January switch would suit both parties.The club have confirmed Marcus Haber has been released after his loan move to Falkirk was cut short.

title: dundee united transfer boost as owner mark ogren hires sporting director
story: New Dundee United owner Mark Ogren has made his first move to improve the club’s fortunes by hiring former agent Tony Asghar as the club’s new sporting director.The American took control of the Tannadice outfit midway through December and has moved quickly to install Asghar, who helped broker the deal between the Minnesota-based businessman and former owner Mike Martin and director Jimmy Fyffe.Former police officer Asghar owns Revolution Global Sports Consulting Ltd, which has interests in the United States and has worked for leading clubs across Europe.Coming in at the start of the transfer window could be a boost to manager Robbie Neilson’s plans to freshen up his squad as they look to reignite their Championship title challenge.Last weekend’s - defeat at Alloa left the Tangerines seven points behind leaders Ross County in the race toto the top flight.Neilson hasn’t hidden his desire to improve the squad he took over in October saying after the defeat to Jim Goodwin’s strugglers that some of his charges weren’t up to the challenge of a title fight.Names of those he’s keen to bring in, however, have been hard to come by.One who has been mentioned is Raith Rovers winger Daniel Armstrong.The former Wolves winger penned a short-term deal at Stark’s Park in November.That expires after the Scottish Cup clash with Dunfermline on January , however.Rovers boss John McGlynn said: “The club has done everything it possibly can and what will be will be. title: jim mcintyre the best man for dundee says tommy wright
story: St Johnstone manager Tommy Wright has expressed sympathy for the “big job” on Saturday’s opposing number Jim McIntyre’s hands after his side “dominated” the Dark Blues.Goals from Scott Tanser and Liam Craig set up the - Premiership success at Dens Park to leave their Tayside rivals bottom of the table going into the winter break.Wright said: “Jim has a big job on his hands and I think he knew that when he took it on. He wasn’t left with much, to be fair.“Jim is the best man Dundee could have to get them out of trouble and I would back him to do that because he’s an experienced manager. It’s a tough league but Jim is a good manager.”Regarding his own side, Wright couldn’t have been happier.He added: “I thought we were excellent. That was as good a performance as I’ve had from any of my teams.“The players were relentless, for  minutes they were at it.“The quality of the play, the energy and the desire to make things happen pleased me.“At - you are always concerned about not getting the second goal but once we did the game was over.“The only thing I can be negative about is that we probably should have had more goals – but that’s six away wins now without losing a goal.“The performance really was top class.”Wright was full of praise for Matthew Kennedy, adding: “Matty was outstanding – people are lining up to kick him now but he’s a strong boy.“You could say Matty was the jewel in the crown of a day with a lot of top performances.”
